conversations.content: A Tale of Beauty: Part One
Crests throughout the land have long used the fearsome dragon as a motif.
While dragons vary wildly in appearance, the classical image that comes to people's minds was created by a painter known as ＂the Dragon's Brushman.＂
Throughout his life, the Brushman painted but a single subject: Lindworm the Lofty, a dragon he chanced to encounter while searching for artistic inspiration.
Lindworm was unsurpassed when it came to beauty, and the moment the artist saw her, he was enraptured beyond words.
As tears streamed down the artist's face, he said, ＂It is a terrible pity, dragon, that you cannot experience such unrivaled beauty for yourself.＂
For this was true: there were no glass mirrors at the time, and metal mirrors shone impure. As such, Lindworm had never seen her own form for what it truly was.
Still, Lindworm was amused by the artist, and took a liking to him. After a moment, she challenged him to recreate her image that she might see this beauty for herself.
The young artist's eyes went wide, not knowing that Lindworm's casual suggestion had just determined the course of his entire career.
A Tale of Beauty: Part Two
Lindworm's desire to know her true beauty motivated the Dragon's Brushman like nothing had before.
Each day, the artist created a new painting of the dragon. And each day she sent him away, disgusted by what she considered to be his meager efforts.
But he continued to return day after day after day. His patrons soon abandoned him. His friends and family fell away. Yet still the Brushman continued.
Destitute and exhausted, the artist soon fell into ill health. And while his paintings grew more and more magnificent, they were never enough to please either himself or Lindworm.
Finally, he stumbled into Lindworm's lair with a painting and said, ＂It is a shame I could not capture your beauty.＂ A moment later, the artist fell down dead.
Lindworm looked at the aged and withered corpse before her and uttered a single word...
The Brushman had his recognition at last, for in the passion and struggle which consumed him, Lindworm had finally seen a beauty unmatched in her long, long life.
